expanded_description: Parabolas have several important properties that describe their shape and behavior. The vertex is the turning point, the axis of symmetry divides the parabola into mirror images, intercepts show where the graph crosses the axes, and the domain and range describe the set of possible inputs and outputs. Understanding these properties is essential for analyzing quadratic functions and their real-world applications.

core_concept.principle:
For a quadratic function $f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c$, key properties include:
• **Vertex**: $(h, k)$ where $h = -\frac{b}{2a}$, $k = f(h)$
• **Axis of symmetry**: $x = h$
• **Y-intercept**: $(0, c)$
• **X-intercepts**: Solutions to $ax^2 + bx + c = 0$
• **Domain**: All real numbers $(-\infty, \infty)$
• **Range**: $[k, \infty)$ if $a > 0$, $(-\infty, k]$ if $a < 0$
• **Increasing/Decreasing**: Decreases on $(-\infty, h)$, increases on $(h, \infty)$ if $a > 0$; opposite if $a < 0$
• **Maximum/Minimum**: Minimum at $(h,k)$ if $a>0$, maximum if $a<0$
core_concept.explanation: Think of a parabola as a mountain or valley. The vertex is the peak (maximum) or the bottom of the valley (minimum). The axis of symmetry is like a mirror line—the left side mirrors the right side. The intercepts are where the parabola touches the ground or the y-axis. The domain tells you all possible x-values (always all real numbers for quadratics), and the range tells you the possible y-values—everything above the minimum or below the maximum.

sections.introduction: The vertex and axis of symmetry are the most important features of a parabola.

introduction_image.alt: Vertex and axis of symmetry on parabola
introduction_image.caption: Figure 12.3.2: Vertex and axis of symmetry.

key_concept.definition: The **vertex** is the point where the parabola changes direction. It is the minimum point if $a > 0$ or the maximum point if $a < 0$. The **axis of symmetry** is the vertical line through the vertex: $x = h$. Every point on the parabola has a mirror point across this line.
key_concept.context: The vertex is the "center" of the parabola—all other features relate to it.

image.alt: Example with vertex and axis labeled
image.caption: Figure 12.3.3: Vertex and axis example.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Vertex and Axis

image.caption: Figure 12.3.4: Find the vertex and axis of symmetry.

worked_examples.problem:
For each quadratic, find the vertex and axis of symmetry:
a) $f(x) = (x - 3)^2 + 4$
b) $g(x) = -2(x + 1)^2 - 5$
c) $h(x) = x^2 - 6x + 5$
d) $p(x) = 3x^2 + 12x + 7$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) Vertex (3,4), axis x=3; b) Vertex (-1,-5), axis x=-1; c) Vertex (3,-4), axis x=3; d) Vertex (-2,-5), axis x=-2
worked_examples.concept_applied: Vertex can be found from vertex form directly or from standard form using the formula.

image.alt: Summary of vertex and axis of symmetry
image.caption: Figure 12.3.5: Vertex and axis summary.

sections.introduction: Intercepts show where the parabola crosses the axes.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 12.3.6: X and Y intercepts of a parabola.

key_concept.definition: The **y-intercept** is the point where the graph crosses the y-axis: $(0, c)$. The **x-intercepts** (also called roots or zeros) are where the graph crosses the x-axis, found by solving $f(x) = 0$. A parabola may have 0, 1, or 2 x-intercepts.
key_concept.context: Intercepts are essential for graphing and for understanding the behavior of the quadratic.

worked_examples.title: Finding Intercepts
worked_examples.problem:
Find the y-intercept and x-intercepts for each quadratic:
a) $f(x) = x^2 - 2x - 8$
b) $g(x) = -x^2 + 6x - 9$
c) $h(x) = 2x^2 + 4x + 3$
d) $p(x) = x^2 - 4x + 4$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Y-intercept is (0,c); X-intercepts are solutions to f(x)=0.

sections.introduction: The domain and range describe all possible input and output values.

introduction_image.alt: Domain and range of a parabola
introduction_image.caption: Figure 12.3.10: Domain and range illustrated.

key_concept.definition: For any quadratic function, the **domain** is all real numbers: $(-\infty, \infty)$. The **range** depends on the vertex and opening direction. If $a > 0$, the parabola opens up, so the range is $[k, \infty)$. If $a < 0$, it opens down, so the range is $(-\infty, k]$, where $k$ is the y-coordinate of the vertex.
key_concept.context: The range is determined by the vertex value and the direction of opening.

worked_examples.title: Finding Domain and Range

image.caption: Figure 12.3.12: Find the domain and range.

worked_examples.problem:
Find the domain and range for each quadratic:
a) $f(x) = x^2 - 4x + 3$
b) $g(x) = -2x^2 + 8x - 5$
c) $h(x) = (x + 1)^2 - 4$
d) $p(x) = 3x^2 + 6x + 2$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) D: $(-\infty,\infty)$, R: $[-1,\infty)$; b) D: $(-\infty,\infty)$, R: $(-\infty,3]$; c) D: $(-\infty,\infty)$, R: $[-4,\infty)$; d) D: $(-\infty,\infty)$, R: $[-1,\infty)$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Domain is always all reals; range depends on vertex and opening direction.

image.alt: Summary of domain and range for quadratics
image.caption: Figure 12.3.13: Domain and range summary.

sections.introduction: Parabolas increase on one side of the vertex and decrease on the other.

introduction_image.alt: Increasing and decreasing intervals on parabola
introduction_image.caption: Figure 12.3.14: Where the parabola increases and decreases.

key_concept.definition:
For a parabola that opens up ($a > 0$):
• Decreasing on $(-\infty, h)$
• Increasing on $(h, \infty)$
For a parabola that opens down ($a < 0$):
• Increasing on $(-\infty, h)$
• Decreasing on $(h, \infty)$
The vertex is where the function changes from increasing to decreasing or vice versa.
key_concept.context: These intervals describe the behavior of the function—whether it's going up or down as you move right.

worked_examples.title: Finding Increasing and Decreasing Intervals
worked_examples.problem:
Find the intervals where each function is increasing and decreasing:
a) $f(x) = x^2 - 6x + 5$
b) $g(x) = -2x^2 + 8x - 3$
c) $h(x) = (x + 2)^2 - 4$
d) $p(x) = 3x^2 - 12x + 7$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) Dec: $(-\infty,3)$, Inc: $(3,\infty)$; b) Inc: $(-\infty,2)$, Dec: $(2,\infty)$; c) Dec: $(-\infty,-2)$, Inc: $(-2,\infty)$; d) Dec: $(-\infty,2)$, Inc: $(2,\infty)$
worked_examples.concept_applied: The vertex is the turning point; direction of opening determines which side is increasing.

image.alt: Summary of increasing and decreasing intervals
image.caption: Figure 12.3.17: Increasing/decreasing summary.

sections.introduction: The vertex represents either the maximum or minimum value of the quadratic function.

key_concept.definition: If $a > 0$, the parabola opens up, and the vertex is the **minimum** point. The minimum value is $k$, occurring at $x = h$. If $a < 0$, the parabola opens down, and the vertex is the **maximum** point. The maximum value is $k$, occurring at $x = h$.
key_concept.context: The maximum or minimum value is the y-coordinate of the vertex and represents the extreme value of the function.

worked_examples.title: Finding Maximum or Minimum Values

image.caption: Figure 12.3.20: Find the maximum or minimum value.

worked_examples.problem:
Determine whether each quadratic has a maximum or minimum value, and find that value:
a) $f(x) = x^2 - 8x + 15$
b) $g(x) = -3x^2 + 6x - 2$
c) $h(x) = 2x^2 + 4x + 1$
d) $p(x) = -x^2 + 10x - 20$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) Min = -1; b) Max = 1; c) Min = -1; d) Max = 5
worked_examples.concept_applied: Sign of a determines max or min; value is the y-coordinate of the vertex.

image.alt: Summary of maximum and minimum values
image.caption: Figure 12.3.21: Max/min summary.

sections.introduction: End behavior describes what happens to the function as $x$ approaches positive or negative infinity.

key_concept.definition: For a quadratic function, as $x \to \infty$, $f(x) \to \infty$ if $a > 0$, and $f(x) \to -\infty$ if $a < 0$. Similarly, as $x \to -\infty$, $f(x) \to \infty$ if $a > 0$, and $f(x) \to -\infty$ if $a < 0$. In other words, both ends go in the same direction—up if $a>0$, down if $a<0$.
key_concept.context: End behavior is determined solely by the leading coefficient $a$.

worked_examples.title: Describing End Behavior
worked_examples.problem:
Describe the end behavior of each quadratic:
a) $f(x) = 2x^2 - 3x + 1$
b) $g(x) = -x^2 + 4x - 7$
c) $h(x) = 0.5x^2 + 2x - 3$
d) $p(x) = -3x^2 - 2x + 5$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) Both ends up; b) Both ends down; c) Both ends up; d) Both ends down
worked_examples.concept_applied: End behavior depends only on the sign of a.

image.alt: Summary of end behavior for quadratics
image.caption: Figure 12.3.25: End behavior summary.

sections.introduction: This table summarizes all the key properties of parabolas for quick reference.

key_concept.definition:
| Property | How to Find | Notes |
|----------|-------------|-------|
| Vertex | $(h,k)$ where $h=-b/(2a)$, $k=f(h)$ | Turning point |
| Axis of Symmetry | $x = h$ | Mirror line |
| Y-Intercept | $(0,c)$ | Always exists |
| X-Intercepts | Solve $f(x)=0$ | 0, 1, or 2 real |
| Domain | $(-\infty, \infty)$ | All quadratics |
| Range | $[k,\infty)$ if $a>0$, $(-\infty,k]$ if $a<0$ | Depends on vertex |
| Increasing | $a>0$: $(h,\infty)$; $a<0$: $(-\infty,h)$ | |
| Decreasing | $a>0$: $(-\infty,h)$; $a<0$: $(h,\infty)$ | |
| Max/Min | $k$ (min if $a>0$, max if $a<0$) | Value at vertex |
| End Behavior | $a>0$: both ends up; $a<0$: both ends down | |
key_concept.context: Keep this table handy for quick reference when analyzing quadratics.

worked_examples.title: Using the Properties Table

image.caption: Figure 12.3.28: Use the table to find properties.

worked_examples.problem:
For $f(x) = -2x^2 + 8x - 3$, use the properties table to find:
a) Vertex
b) Axis of symmetry
c) Y-intercept
d) Domain and range
e) Increasing/decreasing intervals
f) Maximum or minimum value

step_by_step.explanation: Domain all reals; $a<0$, so range $(-\infty, k]$

worked_examples.final_answer: a) (2,5); b) x=2; c) (0,-3); d) D: $(-\infty,\infty)$, R: $(-\infty,5]$; e) Inc: $(-\infty,2)$, Dec: $(2,\infty)$; f) Max = 5
worked_examples.concept_applied: The properties table provides a systematic way to find all key features.

sections.section_title: 12.3.8 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when identifying parabola properties. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Thinking a parabola that opens up has a maximum.
characteristics: For $a>0$, saying the vertex is a maximum

image.caption: Figure 12.3.30: Error - confusing max and min.

examples.process: Error: For $f(x)=x^2$, saying it has a maximum

classifications.value: Writing range as $(-\infty, k]$ for upward opening parabola.
Getting increasing and decreasing intervals backward.
characteristics: Not remembering that up-opening parabolas decrease then increase

worked_examples.title: Correcting Property Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student wrote: 'For $f(x) = -2x^2 + 8x - 3$, the vertex is $(2,5)$, so the range is $[5,\infty)$ and the function is increasing on $(-\infty,2)$.' Identify and correct any errors.

step_by_step.explanation: $a=-2<0$, parabola opens down, so range should be $(-\infty, 5]$
step_by_step.calculation: Student wrote $[5,\infty)$ which is for upward opening

step_by_step.explanation: For $a<0$, increasing on $(-\infty, h)$ is correct

worked_examples.final_answer: Range should be $(-\infty, 5]$. Increasing interval is correct.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Range direction depends on sign of a: up gives $[k,\infty)$, down gives $(-\infty,k]$.

image.alt: Summary table of common property errors and corrections
image.caption: Figure 12.3.34: Common errors summary.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to find all properties of various parabolas.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
For each quadratic, find: vertex, axis of symmetry, y-intercept, x-intercepts, domain, range, increasing/decreasing intervals, and maximum or minimum value.
1) $f(x) = x^2 - 2x - 8$
2) $g(x) = -x^2 + 4x + 5$
3) $h(x) = 2x^2 + 4x - 6$
4) $p(x) = x^2 + 6x + 9$
5) $q(x) = -3x^2 + 6x - 2$

step_by_step.calculation:
Vertex: $h=-6/(2(-3)) = -6/(-6)=1$, $k=-3+6-2=1$ → $(1,1)$
Axis: $x=1$
Y-intercept: $(0,-2)$
X-intercepts: use quadratic formula: $x = \frac{-6 \pm \sqrt{36-24}}{-6} = \frac{-6 \pm \sqrt{12}}{-6} = \frac{-6 \pm 2\sqrt{3}}{-6} = 1 \mp \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$ → approx $(0.423,0)$ and $(1.577,0)$
Domain: $(-\infty,\infty)$, Range: $(-\infty,1]$
Inc: $(-\infty,1)$, Dec: $(1,\infty)$
Max = $1$

worked_examples.final_answer: Complete properties as listed for each function.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Practice finding all key properties of quadratic functions.

summary: Parabolas have several key properties that describe their behavior. The **vertex** $(h,k)$ is the turning point—the minimum if $a>0$, maximum if $a<0$. The **axis of symmetry** $x = h$ divides the parabola into mirror images. The **y-intercept** is $(0,c)$, and **x-intercepts** are found by solving $f(x)=0$. The **domain** of any quadratic is all real numbers $(-\infty,\infty)$. The **range** is $[k,\infty)$ if $a>0$, or $(-\infty,k]$ if $a<0$. **Increasing/decreasing intervals** depend on the vertex: for $a>0$, the function decreases on $(-\infty,h)$ and increases on $(h,\infty)$; for $a<0$, it increases on $(-\infty,h)$ and decreases on $(h,\infty)$. The **maximum or minimum value** is $k$, occurring at $x=h$. **End behavior** is the same in both directions: both ends up if $a>0$, both ends down if $a<0$. Understanding these properties is essential for analyzing quadratic functions and their real-world applications.
